text:
Convo thread:
We sit in front of a computer to do work/research for a Lot of Time Every Day, and with an internet connection to :infinity: amount of possible distractions.
How have you found ways to stay focused?

elements.text:
Convo thread:
We sit in front of a computer to do work/research for a Lot of Time Every Day, and with an internet connection to

amount of possible distractions.
How have you found ways to stay focused?

text: Choose not to enter distracting search terms.

elements.text: Choose not to enter distracting search terms.

text: nope I periodically cycle through twitter, facebook, reddit, discord and slack

elements.text: nope I periodically cycle through twitter, facebook, reddit, discord and slack

text: I am very productive you can probably tell :upside_down_face:

elements.text: I am very productive you can probably tell

text: I found that (after a while) working on a larger 2nd monitor helped me stay with intent

elements.text: I found that (after a while) working on a larger 2nd monitor helped me stay with intent

text: I find I'm productive until I hit a problem then I start seeking a solution/better understanding and then inevitably find something else that is also interesting and start reading/learning about that which inevitably leads to yet more interesting things and so on and so on until my stack overfloweth.  Then I wonder why I didn't get anything done all day! :face_with_rolling_eyes::sweat_smile: I used to jot down things I wanted to accomplish in the margins of whatever paper was on hand, but that resulted in lots of "maybe important" scraps of paper.  Now I try to jot things down in a note taking app on an ipad.  It's a transition, but so far it's working out pretty well :crossed_fingers:

elements.text: I find I'm productive until I hit a problem then I start seeking a solution/better understanding and then inevitably find something else that is also interesting and start reading/learning about that which inevitably leads to yet more interesting things and so on and so on until my stack overfloweth.  Then I wonder why I didn't get anything done all day!

I used to jot down things I wanted to accomplish in the margins of whatever paper was on hand, but that resulted in lots of "maybe important" scraps of paper.  Now I try to jot things down in a note taking app on an ipad.  It's a transition, but so far it's working out pretty well

text: Social media websites have done a remarkable job of reprogramming my brain to mindlessly cycle through them when I come up against a hard problem. I have to use a website blocker if I am working on hard things...

elements.text: Social media websites have done a remarkable job of reprogramming my brain to mindlessly cycle through them when I come up against a hard problem. I have to use a website blocker if I am working on hard things...

text: Same here. A lot of websites are just blocked now or I've put timers on them to reduce the time I spend on them.

elements.text: Same here. A lot of websites are just blocked now or I've put timers on them to reduce the time I spend on them.

text: I don't do it, but I've heard about the timer thing. It's ok to lose focus for a while, you just need to find the spot that doesn't affect going back to the work. It's hard.

elements.text: I don't do it, but I've heard about the timer thing. It's ok to lose focus for a while, you just need to find the spot that doesn't affect going back to the work. It's hard.

text:
I take time to figure out in the morning what I want to accomplish that day.

Then at my desk I use multiple desktops on one 27" screen. I have
1. for the distracting stuff like web-browser, Slack, Reeder,  Ayoa
2. for reading and writing text, graphics,
3. for file management,
4. for development (VSCode, GitKraken, Terminal)
5. for email (also distracting).
Thus at the desk I can switch between focused (2,3,4) and less-focused (1,5). And I have the habit to read non-technical stuff like mails, news, books etc. mostly in another room and on the iPad (un-focused).

Also I find that taking breaks every 30 minutes and concentrating the distracting stuff there is helpful (Pomodoro technique). In short I try to concentrate the distracting stuff in space and time to create space for more focused work.

Also I find that taking breaks every 30 minutes and concentrating the distracting stuff there is helpful (Pomodoro technique). In short I try to concentrate the distracting stuff in space and time to create space for more focused work.

text: I try to avoid random convo threads on the Julia Slack as best I can

elements.text: I try to avoid random convo threads on the Julia Slack as best I can
Ah, damnit!!!

text: More seriously, one thing that has helped me somewhat is to have tab groups in Firefox, with a "General" group that I shouldn't be on most of the time, which has potentially distracting things like Julia Discourse, Slack, Zulip etc., and project specific other groups that only have on-topic tabs of relevant literature, and related Jupyter or Pluto notebooks

text: now I feel unfocused. I go for a run (in the snow). Afterwards I will be able to focus better :man-running:.

elements.text: now I feel unfocused. I go for a run (in the snow). Afterwards I will be able to focus better

attachments.title: The Pomodoro Technique – Why It Works & How To Do It
attachments.text: The Pomodoro Technique is a time management method for students, perfectionists, and procrastinators of all kinds. Work in focused, 25-minute intervals. Take a short break. Repeat.
attachments.fallback: Todoist: The Pomodoro Technique – Why It Works & How To Do It

text: Julia v1.6 problems: Package (pre)compilation is so fast that it took away my excuse to check out Slack/Discourse when my code was compiling before

elements.text: Julia v1.6 problems: Package (pre)compilation is so fast that it took away my excuse to check out Slack/Discourse when my code was compiling before

text: Ah yes, multitasking procrastination on v1.6.
